page.title: 06The Birds of Beeley Moor
page.content: This area supports over a hundred species, many of which are common to any variety of land cover e.g. blackbird, chaffinch and starling. The gritstone moorland is the habitat of the red grouse and it breeds alongside the golden plover, curlew, dunlin and meadow pulpit. The kestrel and sparrowhawk are two of the characteristic moorland birds of prey seen. The wooded gritstone valleys are frequented by goldcrest, redpoll, great tits and willow warbler. The nightjar may be heard on the brackeny hillsides and woodland fringes. The latter provide shelter for woodcock and pheasent. The pasture land of the area supports lapwings, skylarks and windchats whilst near the walls and rocky outcrops can be seen the wheater.
